comment.comment:
Last year somebody was banned from all club activity. More severe punishments exist than apologies. Iâve been welfare secretary for 2 months, and all I wanted to say is that the idea being spread that everyone in the club is the same awful person is wrong, and make public that every uninvolved member supports victims coming forwards. Over the next year Iâll be trying even harder to improve the culture of the club.

Ayotomi IF , nobody can âcontrolâ other people, or âkeep them in lineâ, itâs not possible - and we canât even punish them if we donât know who has done what (club wide allegations have this problem). I want the concerns taken seriously, which was why I suggested the venue through which this can be done.

I take on board your criticisms of my response, but ultimately without formal allegations, we know nothing about whatâs happened - as anyone who does something wrong is definitely not going to say - and a lot of people who are not guilty are told they are scum (while being powerless to stop the behaviour as they donât know who did what).
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
PYHDUGCH RIQFCHA The Union made the decision about what should be done, having tried to put together a full picture, and we followed that decision, as we will in any future scenario.

Ultimately it should be an unbiased body like the union deciding rather than the club itself as there is too much internal politics for hard decisions to be made. The individuals responsible should be held accountable, and I donât think their mistakes should affect the rest of the people in the club.

I am not trying to silence victims, Iâm trying to encourage them to make their voices heard somewhere that can make a difference.

The only way to weed them out is to report them to the union, because uninvolved members of our club donât know about it until it gets reported. We all want this behaviour to stop - I agree that as a club we have more to do.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
VC PYH, I support the actions taken by the union to ban the 6 individuals, as they behaved unacceptably. I wasnât at this social when this happened last year, and I didnât say (nor do I believe) that no guys ever do bad things.

What I said in my previous response to the UCLove allegations was that there are over 100 people in the club who are not a homogenous group, and that I hadnât seen the horrendous things mentioned in that  previous post - which remains the case. 

I also said that people should go to the union with complaints (instead of UCLove) so they can be properly dealt with.

The process that led to this is exactly what should happen when someone behaves like this, as it has identified and punished the correct individuals.

I still actively encourage people to go to the union when they have a problem with anyoneâs actions. I still donât think that less than 6% of a group represent everyone in the group. For what itâs worth, I apologise on behalf of people in the club who werenât involved for not being there to stop what happened, and not successfully changing the culture fast enough.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
I donât want to silence or disregard any voice who wants to speak out.  I can only speak for this year and last year, as freshers donât have access to senior chats, but in this time period, I havenât seen behaviour as is described (Iâve seen rude behaviour - the phineas bus - but never dangerous behaviour). Iâd like to reconfirm that Iâm actively encouraging people to go forwards to the union if you have experienced unacceptable behaviour from a current club member, or feel free to get in touch with me.

In some ways itâs a problem of university sports clubs, as the actions of previous club members affect the whole clubâs reputation down the line. Our club has changed substantively in the past two years, even if the laddy attitude remains. Who would have guessed that last year we would have had an openly gay member of the starting Varsity XV, or be running a touch session jointly with womenâs for all abilities every Saturday (not a huge thing but wouldnât have happened in previous years).

I hope that by trying to explain our club has changed, I am not silencing or ignoring anyone. I just donât think that we should be judged by the actions of predecessors, and I donât think that we should be judged as a homogenous group on an anonymous online forum. If the sad day comes that a member is found having done something unacceptable, I, and the rest of the club, think they should be accused in the appropriate venue (the union), and not on Facebook.

comment.comment:
It's the interest rate which is absolutely ridiculous, it would be at least passable if the loan rose with inflation. It's currently going up by 6% a year, which on a loan of Â£40,000 would be Â£2400 a year. A 9% extra "tax" if it isn't reallly a debt on all income above Â£25k is a huge amount to add onto other taxes for a whole generation of graduates.

If you add to this that the wealthier in society don't take the loans and their parents pay for it, it's actually almost a regressive policy because it hits those who are successful but who aren't from a wealthy enough background to not take the loan in the first place i.e. the middle.

I support a smaller tuition fee of Â£3000, and think that there should be a mixed maintenance loan and grant system where anyone can access loans but grants are for lower income students. I don't really see how funding arrangements would require a dramatic restructuring of higher education in general, surely just funding systems?

In reality, it is a debt because if you earn a medium amount you'll be paying it back for 30 years. Also, there are so many examples of other countries with free education, being better than the USA on this is a non-achievement. We call it a debt because if it got called a graduate tax on middle earners it would have been shot down as it potentially should have been. The punitive interest rate is what realllly kills it as I said. I agree we should encourage working class people to go to university but I feel like what we call it is a smokescreen for worse problems in the system that would have a bigger effect if they were fixed.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
It's the interest rate which is absolutely ridiculous, it would be at least passable if the loan rose with inflation. It's currently going up by 6% a year, which on a loan of Â£40,000 would be Â£2400 a year. A 9% extra tax on all income above Â£25k is a huge policy change if that's what you are advocating for.

The other problem is that yes it does give more money to universities, but often you pay for more than the university is actually spending to teach you and the university goes and spends it on paying their administrative and executive staff spiralling salaries. 

Add to this that the wealthier in society don't take the loans and their parents pay for it, it's actually a not quite a regressive or a progressive tax because it hits those who are successful but who aren't from a wealthy enough background to not take the loan in the first place i.e. the middle.

It's not ideal all in all. It's not awful either, but definitely doesn't do the job it's supposed to.

comment.comment: RUPCX DCFALCG I'm more inclined to be very doubtful of any of the gods worshipped by humans over the course of history as being real, or even a good representation of any powerful being(s) that may exist/have existed. So I am an atheist, in that I lack belief in religions/reckon religions are probably wrong.  But also an agnostic: I accept the logical truth that it is impossible to prove nonexistence, and that there may be some indifferent (I.e. abandoned us) higher power(s), and I have no way of knowing for certain. But practically, we live under the same everyday assumptions it seems ð
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: Atheists can be agnostic, they actually describe different "lacks" in terms of religion. A-theist, means a lack of belief in a deity, a-gnostic means a lack of knowledge/certainty about deities. You can be an agnostic or a gnostic atheist, depending on if you think you are certain there are no gods, or just pretty sure, but accept you lack conclusive proof.

comment.comment:
Reconsider the student loan repayments as an extra tax bracket: 9% of everything you earn above Â£21,000. That would take you to 29% in the basic tax bracket and up to 49% on anything above Â£43,000. People would be fuuurious about that if you tried to impose that on people. That is an incredibly punitive tax rate to place on people going to university. If the fees were lower, say around Â£3,000 a year, and the repayments were 5% a year, then maybe that would be reasonable.

Also, until you start paying tax on earnings above about Â£38,000, you are net taking from the state, and even after that, there is a lot of other things that I'd hope you'd not be so penny pinching on such as pensions + healthcare + normal education, so don't start worrying about your tax bill going on educating young people until you earn serious money.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: You are right, and I guess the idea is not to disregard the current struggle, but to show some grounds for hope that through long hard struggle we can actually improve the world. Knowing that what weâve tried to do has made a difference should inspire us to try and do more things. The news doesnât report positive general trends because they arenât good commercial copy, so there can sometimes be this feeling that the world is getting worse, because there are more scandals and natural disasters that we know about. And, iff that was the case that would be a depressing reality because it would mean all the people trying and hoping for it to be better arenât succeeding at all. These âgood news statisticsâ try to counter that narrative, so we can approach current problems in the knowledge that even though our attempts wonât make things perfect, hopefully they will make things better. Change will still be tough, and thereâs still a long way to go.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
When talking of people, you are right that equality should not mean the same. The same is one of the definitions of equal/equality, but it is the other ones that I think we should apply, attached here. I think that people should be treated without prejudice/discrimination and without disrespect, given equal inherent value as human beings, and that we should try to give equal opportunities (in the sense of fair rather than make every job application a lottery) to everyone.

I see why you wrote what you wrote, and agree with you in the sense that you wrote it, but I think that because equal and equality have multiple meanings, you have missed out the meanings under which people should be "equal".

comment.comment: DODUH UIL there are two kinds of "unlimited" wants. One is unlimited in terms of sheer quantity. More of everything. But I don't think that that is a real problem to be solved, it is clearly impossible. More interesting is the problem of satisfying wants that are unlimited in terms of variety, and higher quality. This is solveable, and while unlimited living standards (what wants translate into when satisfied, demerit goods aside) clearly can't be achieved, we can achieve better living standards, and that should be the goal of all modern economics. What would providing everyone with free basic foods do that would be bad? As long as you made sure that you incentivised producers enough, avoiding the supply problem that affects economies without enough incentives (state socialist ones we've seen), it would be fine.

comment.comment: GIHU U. Frederick  Lol, maybe you are either a theist or an atheist (although I don't see why someone could not say they hadn't yet decided/were unable to decide), but there are different types of both. you can be a gnostic or agnostic atheist, and a gnostic or agnostic theist. Which means that Agnositicism is not the same as Atheism, refuting your claim. This whole paper chair thing is ridiculous, I'm with Sona on that side argument.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comments.title: ACWBUYF.XYFFS replied to Sona G. Frederick's comment.

comment.comment: GIHU U. Frederick I think that atheism/theism is just about whether or not one holds a belief, and agnosticism is about whether or not one claims that it is a justified true belief (gnostic atheist/theist) or whether they don't know (agnostic atheist/theist). Gnostics claim knowledge (that their belief is justified true), agnostics do not. Works perfectly as the distinction. Atheists lack a belief in god, but some claim that their lack of belief is the truth, the gnostic atheists. (They claim to have a justified true belief about their lack of belief). Those who don't claim justified true belief about their lack of belief, are agnostic atheists.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comments.title: ACWBUYF.XYFFS replied to Sona G. Frederick's comment.

comment.comment: An atheist claims they hold no belief, an agnostic claims they cannot know, given the information they hold. They are different. One can be a gnostic atheist, and claim that they know that their lack of belief is correct.

comment.comment:
DODUH UIL demand pull is the only economic argument against giving people helicopter money, which is why I think its death is significant. There are exceptions where good production is restricted by locality or regulation such as housing, or by monopolies restricting output such as oil.

I don't see Yellen's tightening making some massive dent in demand unless they tighten really hard. Anything that causes a new debt crisis (tighter monetary policy could do this but would have to be stupid) is my black swan, consumer debt is worryingly high right now.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
HBY QBCHYMY debt one sounds interesting but they didn't tell us how much it was as a % of GDP.

I think that the only type of recession there will be is a collapse in demand, for the same reason why I think that demand pull inflation is non-existent. Global supply is now so elastic in the short term that demand is what mainly determines the size of the (developed) economy, and cost push inflation by far outweighs demand pull.

comment.comment:
I don't think that aliens are something that you can "believe in" or not believe in right now, as it is a matter of establishing fact, rather than religious belief which is about faith.

However, you can think that the possibility of aliens existing is likely, without "believing in" aliens. If that's what religious people did with deities, simply thought it was likely that a particular god existed, then this analogy would work. Because that's not the case, I think the analogy fails.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
The mouth is not only to eat, it is a multi-purpose part of the body that also communicates, tastes, cuts/mashes (using teeth), kisses, etc. etc.

The penis is not only to reproduce, it is a multi-purpose part of the body that also urinates and produces great pleasure when stimulated, and it is not only through reproduction that it can be stimulated - it gets used far more often for pleasure, perhaps biologically we need pleasure to motivate us, and in fact the pleasure function of the penis is at least as important as the reproductive function?

The anus is primarily for discharging waste, yeah. But we do have a prostate for some reason that provides pleasure when stimulated, wonder what the biological function of a pleasure organ stimulated by anal sex is.

Biology is confusing, and homosexuality works within that system. I think declaiming biological purposes (or nature's intended purpose - nature does not have intentions) of organs simplifies a complex system of multipurpose organs, so doesn't really work as a paradigm through which to judge things.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Finance wise, joining the military entitles you to free healthcare if I'm not wrong, comprehensive health insurance. So the costs of transitioning aren't an argument. Time off work? Like any non-physical health issue, time off work is standard, and encouraged in fact, in order to help you be able to resolve it. No problem there: even if they have more time off than the average military personnel, they are still doing military work most of the time. Culture within the military? Well much like it needed to change about gay people and women being in the military, why would this be any different, it should be able to tolerate, or better, accept trans people too. Having trans people working in it shouldn't make the "culture" less effective any more than having women and gay people would.

the argument that the military is there to protect the country first and foremost and no studies so far suggest that allowing transgender people into it increase its ability to do that, unlike women where studies suggest it does................ Yeah, let the military protect the country, and let people who want to contribute join the military. Unless you can show me unequivocal proof that having a trans person working for the military makes the absolute effectiveness of the military lower (not average, absolute), then there is no reason why they should not have the freedom to do so. It's the same story as it was for allowing racism in the military, homophobia in the military and sexism in the military. Totally baseless reactionary crap, justified by baseless reactionary crap.

comment.comment:
Railway nationalisation works across the globe, water I'm not concerned about who runs it (if states can run trains they can run water).

Post office got sold at a discount, and was a publicly run competitor that helped provide downward pressure on private firms prices.

He proposed pay ratios for firms winning public contracts to ensure taxpayers money doesn't get skimmed into a CEOs pay packet - responsible allocation of taxpayers money. The Labour Party wouldn't roll that out anywhere else, because that justification doesn't work anywhere else, and companies that don't take public money are under no obligation to the taxpayer.

I do know the difference between zero hour be temporary, it's the article you shared that chose to falsely equate them. They aren't banning zero hours contracts, simply mandating that workers have the option of being guaranteed how much they will work each week in order to be able to plan their lives. Roadies could have temporary contracts rather than zero hours contracts, was my point, so that writer's claim that roadies would have to be paid outside tour dates is bullshit.

I think that Â£10 for 16 year olds is excessive yes, but equal pay for equal work should definitely be a thing. If it could be shown that 16 year olds are just as productive then fair enough but I kind of doubt that that's the case.

Discussing the track records of nationalised industries competing with a newly globalised economy where coal miners and steel workers now have to compete with desperate dirt poor workers being exploited in unregulated countries to undercut western workers is a very complex issue that can't be boiled down to "nationalisation bad". Plenty of private companies failed for the same reasons. Railway usage after a prolonged period of serious economic strife is going to be lower.

I don't support nationalisation as a point of principle, only where there is proof (models in other countries) that a particular natural monopoly can operate better in public hands or in privÃ¢t hands, or where there is evidence that higher consumption of that good will be beneficial for the whole of the economy, like healthcare and education. I think Royal Mail fits the second category, and that railways fit the first one, and water I don't know anything about.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comments.title: ACWBUYF.XYFFS replied to his own comment.

comment.comment:
Haha, more straw in that article than at Glasto.

1970s, tax rates were far too high, and the Labour Party aren't thinking of going anywhere close. In 1971 the top rate of income tax on earned income was cut to 75% from 90%. A surcharge of 15% kept the top rate on investment income at 90%. In 1974 the cut was partly reversed and the top rate on earned income was raised to 83%. With the investment income surcharge this raised the top rate on investment income to 98%, the highest permanent rate since the war. This applied to incomes over Â£20,000 (Â£187,970 as of 2015),[7]. In 1974 750,000 people were liable to pay the top-rate of income tax. - Wikipedia, History of taxation in the UK

Labour's tax rises wouldn't make anyone move anywhere, and equating them to the 1970s is utterly ridiculous.
Minimum wages - if Glasto is sooo bourgeouis, then the food would still be affordable even if you have to pay caterers Â£10 an hour, and the festival is plenty profitable to pay security Â£10 an hour - look at the founder's support for Corbyn.
Contract changes - totally intentional misunderstanding of what banning a zero hours contract would mean. Temporary contracts still perfectly possible, for the length of tour or whatever, he has made that up.
Pay ratios for bands? This writer is a joke, "a corbyn government would presumably....." sure presume whatever total fantasy you like.
And of course, let's imagine Corbyn will cap prices for everything including festival tickets, and nationalise everything too, because that is a fair representation of a social democratic manifesto that embraces the best parts of capitalism while trying to not leave the impoverished behind.

Wooo, yeah, let's cite a spectator blog by some funny(straw)man as if it holds any water, because people might just see the article and assume that its sensationalist headline has any truth to it whatsoever.

Apologies for the tone of some of what I've written if it's a bit unfair.

I think that state planning for 20-40 years has actually been shown to work pretty well to bring large amounts of an economy out of poverty, but I agree that there should be a transition to capitalism once basic education, infrastructure and health have been sorted out through planning

He makes an economic case which he doesn't back up in this short video, where he says it leads to worse growth over time.

I don't see why the link you sent is relevant? Talks about 2010. Investing in education, housing, infrastructure and health is to my mind the best way any government can prime an economy for growth. In this way the government creates HUUge economic value by massively increasing the productivity of its labour force. To call it an orgy of public spending is to massively misrepresent it.

Interest on student debt makes it unaffordable, and makes it an effective  9% increase in income tax in the bracket of Â£21,000 and above, which in any other context would be scandalous, but because it is a "loan" rather than a graduate income tax, is apparently fine. comment.comment:
I think it's fair to protest against governing with the DUP - especially if you voted Tory and don't support the coalition. I think it's fair to let the governing party know that you don't support their leader through protest. I'd just like to compare protest to the media. If the media called on May to resign, or called on other journalists to provide political pressure to get the leader out, would that be as outrageous? Would you, if a Telegraph journalist had called for May's resignation, be just as outraged?

McDonnell is questionable, I agree, but in terms of policy outcomes from their victory, I can only see Labour as being good for the country. People actually protested against Trump, not just his policies, just for the record, and all of the protests have been aimed at expressing discontent at his presidency.

I think it is fair to protest/rally for absolutely anything as long as it is non violent and you can get people involved. It is a valid way of expressing your political opinion, and even if you think that the reason they are protesting for is dumb, wrong, distasteful, they still have a right to protest. And feel free to go and form an anti-protest against them - see the EDL marches.

comment.comment:
I in fact didn't know that they were on that committee. I wonder how well informed that committee was about the renovations they were passing through, or the state of the block, I don't imagine they were able to go to the block itself, although perhaps they had some residents' complaints, I don't know. Everyone who has some responsibility for the critical lack of care taken to maintain the block needs to take a long hard look at themselves. I think that a large proportion of your political party voting against a bill that could have had a significant effect on some of the worse landlords across britain is certainly something that you should think about quite hard.

It seems like the independent review was not fit for purpose, and that the oversight committee was not fit for purpose, and in fact that deprived areas like these simply do not get adequate levels of attention from government at any level, and that needs to be addressed. I think it was Akala who said that this simply would never have happened to a rich, luxury tower of flats, because they aren't forced by their economic situation to stay in poor unsafe conditions and because they would find it far easier to make the council listen. The cladding was put on in order to make the tower less of an eyesore.

Public enquiries often mean absolutely fuck all. They are more often an obfuscation of the situation that leads to no actionable findings and a 10,000 page report, in which nobody gets blamed and nothing gets done. It seems unlikely that this enquiry will be any different, and I would imagine that any of the landlords in this country that are indeed "pesky" will see no change in the way they have to operate at all as a result of it.

I'm sorry but it's not just about local governance. Boris Johnson when pressed about cuts to the fire service boorishly dismissed another MPs concerns as "guff" or something like that, and passing that law would have sent a message to landlords and given councils more power to make things happen. Cuts to council funding surely play a part in this as it makes them unable to adequately carry out their duties (and a lot of Conservative austerity was just pushed to councils, passing the buck). 

I don't see how passing legislation to make homes fit for human habitation can reasonably be called "unnecessary legislation" when you end up with an tower block where neither the sprinklers nor the fire alarms work and the refurbishment that was done put in cosmetic cladding that wasn't fire retardant (in fact seemed to burn very easily). It is not low to show a clear link between your parties policies and the causes of a tragedy, when your party voted to put less pressure on landlords to make their properties safe and secure. Who are the people really at risk here? I really don't think that it's the landlords at risk of "unnecessary regulation" who we should be worrying about, and yet that is exactly what the Conservative party has done year upon year, government upon government.

comment.comment:
I don't support all the positions of the Labour leaders themselves, rather I strongly support the manifesto and I strongly support about 80% of Corbyn's views. As far as I'm concerned, any non violent protest is "innocent", in that it only functions as a form of political pressure no more powerful (mostly significantly less powerful) than political pressure from the media and political pressure from powerful wealthy people. Protest in itself simply cannot oust a democratically elected leader, but it is totally within its rights to express their dissatisfaction with that leader and their wish for that leader to go, much like the protests against Trump - or do you condemn them just as strongly?

If protest could force a government to go, then I would agree with you. Given that it can't, and it is simply a way for large groups of people to apply political pressure, I think it's fine.

It's worth remembering we don't have democratically elected leaders, we actually have democratically elected parties who elect their leaders, and so I would argue it is fair to protest against their selection/continued support of that leader.

The DUP is very far right on social matters, it is at heart a theocratic party that is homophobic, anti women's (reproductive) rights, and denies climate change. While it certainly isn't the most far right party in Europe, there aren't many more far right parties than the DUP in Western Europe and I'd say it's top 10 in the right wing rankings out of any parties with some significance.

The liberal right protest through the media and through their economically magnified political voice. For them (forgive my stereotyping here, I think it is roughly fair however), going out on the streets is a waste of money. Street protest is not their most effective way of getting their voice heard so it makes sense that they wouldn't do that.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comments.title: ACWBUYF.XYFFS replied to his own comment.

comment.comment:
The liberal right by and large demographically don't have much to protest about. There isn't all that much arm twisting and shadow boxing nowadays is there? Haven't seen much of it? Unless you mean doctors protesting about the stretching of the NHS or (more arguably selfish) rail strikes (although they still had a point of sorts).

I am at least as annoyed as you at those members of the left who see politics as a shouting match. It frustrates me a lot to see it happen. But without making any noise and showing any dissent, you can be very sure that nothing will change. Protest allows for political expression outside of the party political system in this country, which I think is very important.

Obviously I disagree with McDonnell if he said that, I would like a link to that interview just to know better what he is like.

Unions have some power but I would say you are exaggerating their influence for your own reasons. They really aren't that big a deal most of the time, they are just helpful for workers to organise in order to redress the huge imbalance of power normally found between employers and employees, and for that I think they are both useful and important.

The London riots originally began as a protest against the killing or internment (I don't remember which) of a man that his community believed was innocent. I can see why that would be condoned. Obviously they spread way out of control and became selfish pursuits of personal gain during a time of chaos, which is deplorable. But the original reasoning behind why they occurred was fair enough.

Why do you think that it is unacceptable to protest against a democratically elected leader? Especially given their abandonment of principle to form a coalition with one of the most far right parties in Europe? I think it's fine to protest trump, and it is fine to protest may. To be honest, protest what you like if enough people care about it enough.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Haha, I definitely don't think that centrally planned state socialism is the way. Venezuela is an awful situation that has come about partially because of a terribly managed state socialist system, which I think is a very bad way to run a country (however it is a straw man to compare labour's plans to what has happened in Venezuela). I want capitalism to be how economies function, but for the government's role to be providing more merit goods and investing in the future economy, and giving people good educations regardless of their background.

I'm sure it's easier to confuse the system that led to Venezuela's total failure with the moderate proposal for more taxation that Labour have proposed than it is to actually argue against investing in a sustainable economy by educating our people and making sure that the essential bases of a healthy economy are there (education, health, housing and infrastructure), but Venezuela isn't even close to what Labour are campaigning for. Look at Scandinavia if you want a better idea.

comment.comment:
The whole point of protest is that it is a mechanism to counteract the problem of tyranny of the majority. Protest is of course a minority thing, but that's as it should be. It is in some sense a donation to a political cause, and allows those who don't have huge amounts of money to donate (Conservative party donors) with their time and voice to a cause they believe in. It is the only way in which those without wealth can make their voice heard. If "respecting the result of a democratic election" means shutting up while the conservatives form an alliance with the DUP and pursue a hard brexit, then I think that that would be a travesty. Accepting the result doesn't mean minorities staying silent, it means not going and violently changing it. A protest against an outcome that is democratic is an entirely valid method of political expression.

Nobody is saying that those people with placards should make all the decision, but they are allowed to speak up on what they want. Because democracy isn't just about voting once every five (or two ð) years.

Protest isn't dangerous, claiming that protest is dangerous is dangerous.

comment.comment:
She was more than terrible under campaigning, it became clear that she was terrible under pressure and didn't had a clue what the country wanted. Jeremy's weakness was this circular argument of people thinking he was unelectable and then not supporting him, reinforcing this unelectability.

The reason why they didn't win the election is because of the lack of belief among the PLP, the media, and therefore the labour campaigners, that they could win. We won nearly every seat we targeted, just that because of the horrendous predictions we didn't end up targeting anywhere near enough seats.

This is the main reason why they didn't win. Your claim that there is no reason they shouldn't win is again totally misregarding context. From a position where he didn't have the backing of his party and where the media attacked him day after day after day, he managed to get 40% of the vote. If the PLP had backed him, and polling numbers didn't threaten huge losses, we would have campaigned in Amber Rudd's seat, and tens or other seats, and could have potentially won them.

Labour were fighting a defensive campaign trying to achieve damage limitation. They ended up increasing vote share by more than any other election since Atlee, taking votes from every single other party. If you think that there is no such thing as momentum in politics then look at Corbyn's and May's post election appearances on Andrew Marr, look at their body language.

The conservatives in a minority government was more than any labour supporter could hope for a month ago. It's the defiance of expectations which is the key thing. You can't win if you don't target enough seats to win because you are fighting defensively because of poll numbers and lack of support from loud voices.

The hard and short of the matter is that "in power" is a very strong term for not having a majority and facing a huge struggle to pass any legislation. I think you are wrong about who will end up helping in brexit negotiations. Please keep ignoring context and claiming that nothing can be learned from defying the huge power of the media and New Labour to get 40% of the vote (that would have won the last 3 elections). If the rest of the conservatives believe they have won, then I'm happy. Polling numbers now suggest labour are above conservatives. Look at the change in support. Hugely meaningful. Anyway, let's wait until the next election, shouldn't be long!
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Contexxxtttt why don't you understand context Nat. Consider it in terms of what "lines" each party used to use and how damaged their credibility is now, and what their future potential is. Conservatives no longer can use strength, stability, or competence as a political argument, which has always been their main line. Corbyn is now quite obviously electable (40% of the vote is a hugely electable amount) and post election polling shows labour having overtaken conservatives. Conservatives are dropping their principles like flies to stay in power, and look awfully placed for the next election, while Labour hasn't seen such an energised base or such passion or such good ground game for decades, if not forever. You are kidding yourself if you think that this election shows electoral faith in the tories.

Corbyn may not have gotten a degree but he has been learning all his life, which is more important that going for some degree that doesn't teach you that much.

Labour suddenly look best placed for the next election. The Tories have been forced to try to get into bed with the DUP (which looks awful), and it's looking like this election might lead to a soft brexit - which is the most important outcome possible from this election. That is a successful campaign for labour, especially in Context, especially when seeing how much polling numbers changed, especially seeing how many doubters have been proven wrong. It's twee to dismiss it as "oh you still lost" because it means that you aren't taking into account the implications of this election for Brexit and for future elections.

VULLS POLXIH so because it benefits both you and society, both of you should pay? Let's take that argument a bit further. The NHS benefits both you and society, so you should both pay. If you choose to go to uni, why should the taxpayer foot the bill; if you choose to go to the doctor why should the taxpayer foot the bill.

Roads and their maintenance benefit both you and society so you should both pay. If you choose to go to uni, why should the taxpayer foot the bill; if you choose to drive on the roads why should the taxpayer foot the bill.

Go to the police, need the fire brigade, etc.

The main idea of a collectivised government, with a welfare state and public services to help society and the economy function, is to collectivise costs in order to best benefit society. I'd be ok with 3k a year, but 9k is just unreasonable. Free education would in effect give everyone's kids the chance to go to uni, which I think can only be a good thing - especially when combined with a funded school system that can compete with the world.

comment.comment: Yeah all this stuff pisses me off, but I am economically left wing, and I don't think that having a different governing party will really change how our military functions. In general on nukes, it's like having a massive sledgehammer, when everything you are trying to do is actually represented by small nails and pins. We have a military that is able to act with huge precision and overwhelming force without nukes, it would be a rare situation where nukes are a better option in terms of military effect than anything else. In terms of as a deterrent, you have to press it if they press it (unless you can stop/disarm the nuke, which I would have thought you could but idk). I'm voting labour despite some clear issues and despite some things I disagree with. The future of our economy here is more important, and right now what it needs is investment spending, both in capital and (most importantly) in education. The IRA, Diane Abbott, nukes, in terms of how I want the country governed, I think they just aren't as key issues as fiscal policy and government investment. ðð

It's for 'transparency' is it? The information is in the manifesto, totally public, in what way is an MP knowing it any more transparent? She could have just reminded the public of it, equally transparent.

"Never memorize something that you can look up" - Albert Einstein

Of course that information needs to be made known to the public, but why is there a need for every MP to accurately remember every single number in the manifesto when it is all publicly available.

Michael Farron struggled to remember whether the party at good ol' Assad's place was a reception or an election party to celebrate a brutally repressive dictator's "reelection".

Put a party on trial for the content of its manifesto and discuss that, ask if the proportion is too high, and feel free to remind the politicians of the numbers they don't know. comment.comment: BIQ W have a challenge for you. You critique the use of philosophies that are "western" to analyse these problems. Provide alternatives then, how else should we evaluate if something is moral. Show me other philosophies of ethics that we can use. I don't care what culture an idea comes from, I will evaluate it on its own merit. If you wish to critique something as being "so western", tell me what other things we should consider to have a more balanced perspective?
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: The inquisition. Who said that was fair? The crusades. They were called righteous by religion, but anyone who was not in thrall to the religion wouldn't have agreed. No philosophical underpinnings. That was just classic human behaviour with no philosophical justification to it, only theological.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: YQUGY OHNBIHS Appiah did a Reith Lecture called "Culture" that you can find on BBC player, that talks about whether "western" culture is even a description which holds any value.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: CE W'm done, have a read and tell me whether you still think there is no way to fairly compare societies and actions.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: There is one philosophy of ethics I haven't mentioned. Nihilism. Under nihilism, nothing has any meaning anyway and so nothing can be right or wrong. Nihilism is where cultural and moral relativism come from, where nothing is good and nothing is bad and everything is equally neutral. You can't learn anything from nihilism, nor can you structure a society that allows its people whatever things you think are good.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: And then once you have answers to those questions, you judge individual societies and/or you compare the extent to which your chosen philosophy(ies) of ethics show them to be in the right.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Does it aim to provide the greatest good for the greatest number of people? (utilitarianism)
If we agree that certain ideals are "good" things to strive for (equality, fairness, freedom), does this society/action aim at those goods? (Deontological)
Is this society one that a virtuous man would wish for/construct?(Aristotlean Virtue ethics)
Does this society ensure that each member of society first have access to basic liberties and secondly is structured so as to benefit those who are the least well off? (Rawlsian)
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: So, you take these ideas, and then look at a particular action or society and ask the relevant questions about it so that you can try to figure out if it is a good or bad society
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: Rawls' Theory of justice is also an important contribution to the study of what is right and what is wrong
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: Utilitarianism is often considered the most popular one but you have others which rest on vaguer foundations such as the deontological System (where are you agree beforehand what is important and then argue from there) or Aristotlean virtue ethics (where what is right is said to be what some imaginary virtuous man would do - naturally there will be assumptions as to what constitutes a virtuous man)
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: You have various different theories of ethics and you can choose to consider one of them or all of themor a combination of them that you feel is relevant but you should try to justify why you choose one theory or the other
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: Right. So when's you approach questions of ethics, you need to look at the different philosophical theories that underpin or dictate what is ethical
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
The argument for immigration has mostly nothing to do with trying to alleviate world poverty (and taking in refugees should not be considered the same as taking in immigrants). The Straw Man argument is one which sets up a low-quality/false version of the opposition argument to knock it down easily, as we see here.

Immigration policy today is about making sure the ageing population being a tax burden is balanced out by people of working age paying tax, it's about filling the gaps in our workforce with people who can do those jobs (see NHS, catering). I'll admit that part of the reason why people think immigrants are stealing jobs is because the adult training/apprenticeship programs in the UK and the US have been neglected and run down for so many years, but that's not the fault of immigrants.

TL:DR - we don't take in immigrants out of some altruistic attempt to solve world poverty. We do it for the needs of our own economy.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: A jury of ones peers is supposed to be less corruptible than a judge (not necessarily more correct, it's much like democracy in that way - not always perfect but it's supposed to stop dictators from exploiting the population), and as it's done in secrecy, less pressurised to conform to public opinion than a majority vote
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: what is the strange culture that has been foisted on it? I don't think you can blame colonisation for the burning of a 7 year old child. For me, Barbarism can be measured by both willingness to put people to death, and the pain/gruesomeness of the method. The guillotine is quite a non-barbaric way to execute someone. Capital punishment is more barbaric than no capital punishment, and within capital punishment, the guillotine is less barbaric than burning or the electric chair.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: In general it makes more sense to incentivise the low cost low emission mode of transport that is cycling. If every cyclist had a car, traffic in London would be appalling. In general, it requires truly appalling cycling skills to threaten serious or fatal injury to others. Skipping red lights is annoying but they're the ones risking their own skin there, it's on them if they cycle into traffic. Cyclists cause minimal wear on roads, and minimal environmental damage. Roads aren't just for cars, and the difficulty of a test should be based on the danger you may pose to others.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Why the same post again? Same comment again ;)

Cherry picking statements from scientists who happen to be religious (the indoctrination has been going on for too long for there to be none), making unverified, generalised claims about what "scientists" are now doing and saying. It would have a lot more integrity as an article if it addressed why there are trillions of stars and planets if only one is inhabited? If instead millions more are in fact inhabited, then surely we wouldn't be special at all.

It also should be noted that just because we doesn't know something, it doesn't mean it was god. We don't know if there are multiple universes, and we don't know what happened before the universe did. It might be a constant cycle of contractions and expansions, it could be an entirely impersonal and alien being who doesn't even know this universe exists. It's a complete hypothesis. There's also the observation fallacy about being here to marvel at the unlikelihood of a universe that contains life. There are also over 2700 (not counting the Hindu millions) distinct Gods that humans have created over the last 10 million years. Any other one of those 2700 has just as valid a claim to truth as yours.

I don't believe any God that has been worshipped by humans could possibly be the real one. If they really were, they must be so powerless to affect the world, to not be able to convince all (particularly the more educated ones on average -obviously there are very clever religious people but the average atheist is more educated) their creations of their existence. Or they don't care enough to convince all their creations, and instead are willing to watch them suffer in an eternal hell. I could go on all day. So many reasons why no Abrahamic god exists.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
HIG ROZUFF  so it wouldn't just be a one size fits all policy, an owner occupied house or a first home would be tax exempt, for precisely that reason. And imagine the extra money one would get from the scrapping of income tax.

It really doesn't encourage cash in hand/splashing out unless you are unable to invest your money at above perhaps 3%. The tax wouldn't need to be higher than roughly 1%. Investing money at 3% (inflation+1% based on BofE target) would keep it's value (the inflation target is 2% obviously it varies but higher inflation means the economy is probably doing better). Investing at higher than inflation+1% would be the aim rather than just higher than inflation. It would be simple to have a wealth allowance as well, but the scrapping of income tax would probably mean that people wouldn't need it.

If rental prices go up, so does the incentive to get into renting (thus putting prices back down). The small payments to the government when renting your second/tenth home out would be covered by the rent, and if the rent wasn't high enough to cover the costs, the value of the house would go down until the correct equilibrium was reached.

Feel free to invest your money anywhere you like, houses or other investments, and if you make more than a 1% real value gain on your investment annually, then you are doing fine.

You are correct that the current inheritance tax system does create problems. It should probably be cleared up, but it definitely shouldn't be scrapped. What's yours should be yours sounds nice. How about what was your great great great great grandfather's should be yours? How about we need to find money to spend on the things that the country needs most that aren't being provided by the private sector (investment in infrastructure, healthcare, education, community projects and welfare)? The reason why inheritance tax is good is because the people inheriting are doing fine before they inherit. It isn't taking money out of their bank account, rather it is just reducing the windfall they receive (makes it a less positive amount rather than a negative amount).

I think taxing when you earn is stupid. It means that someone with billions of familial wealth earnings Â£60k gets taxed less than someone who is first generation out of university earning Â£80k. It's a travesty for social mobility and any attempt to redistribute wealth or have a nation that doesn't have rapidly, constantly increasing inequality (which correlates with a  lot of negative societal outcomes).

I agree the state should be an essential background. Education, healthcare, infrastructure and wealth redistribution. Your money should be your own, but this is just a different way of deciding how much everyone contributes to the systems our country needs. The richer you are, the more you benefit from the country having a well educated and healthy populace who can commute easily (because you employ them or invest in companies that do). So because you benefit more, you should contribute more. Basing it on income makes far less sense.

It would still remain your choice what you did with your money. It wouldn't be unfair at all, and of course one would try and get rid of loopholes. You aren't paying the government to keep hold of your property, you are paying them for all of the systems that need to be in place for you to live, work, eat, get healthcare, education, travel, be safe.... because without money they couldn't exist. That is what you are paying for.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Hey tom how's it going? :) Why should wealth not decay over time if you do absolutely nothing? A wealth tax (the premise this land tax is based on) would actually incentivise investment and saving, because what would happen is in order to maintain or increase wealth, you would need to invest money above the tax+inflation. People would try to make their money work harder, but it would also mean that everyone's after tax incomes would be significantly increased (as they are no longer taxed).

Replacing the income tax with a wealth tax would be a huge step forward. It would increase social mobility more than almost any other change in history has, and it would allow for redistribution of wealth to occur as it is supposed to. I don't believe that my great great grandfather's accomplishments should mean that I am so wealthy I don't have to work, do you?

I think that each generation should be able to pass on a large proportion of the gains from their work (60% as it currently stands), but that there should be a constant equalising pressure where money is taken proportionally to how much money people actually have, and put into services and education for the whole country to benefit from.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
VCFXUB AOMCEUPUHBO  the most recent David greensmith comment seems like a fairly significant rebuttal of your point. There are some clearly immoral commandments in Mosaic law, the ones mentioned above being examples. What category is it OK for there to be an immoral commandment in back in those days. Why didn't God condemn slavery or rape? They surely cannot come under civil rules or worship rules.

"Love your neighbour as yourself" wasn't invented by Christianity by any means. It is everywhere from ancient Babylon Chinese philosophy, and the same for all the non-religious Ten Commandments.

The OT is completely defined by its historical and cultural contexts, with absolutely nothing in it which suggests any divine hand guiding the writing of it, nothing that couldn't have been known at that time. No new moral revelations, no new information about the world, no new philosophical ideas. Same with the NT. A book with divine truth in it and a divine hand guiding it should either have been written to apply to all cultures, or be clear about what is supposed to expire upon the coming of the Messiah and what is not. Instead, it allows everyone their own interpretation, causing suffering and strife. Also it should have been clearer about when this messiah guy was gonna come, because obviously loads of Jews think Jesus wasn't the real messiah, which should have been really really clear, given he was "god's son". Don't see where the ambiguity could have come from.

comment.comment:
It is impossible to prove the non existence of a non existent object. Take the Flying Spaghetti Monster, or a half-unicorn half-dragon. There is no way to go about proving they don't exist.

Now we can use logic to disprove certain characteristics  being present in the same being. All loving, all powerful and all knowing cannot exist in the same being.

No proof can be provided that there is no God of any kind at all (although it would violate the laws of physics most probably), in the same way as we cannot prove that sentient spaghetti doesn't exist.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: People who rise above problem backgrounds don't show that problem backgrounds don't matter. They are outliers, incredibly talented, and spurred on by a consistent underdog mentality. In the same way as you get people with perfect backgrounds who fuck everything else, you get amazing people like this girl. But you have to look at what is statistically significant, which is that for your average person who doesn't have Olympic level talent and all the other things that make this girl amazing, background matters a whoooole lot. Rich people stay rich and poor people stay poor and a few move in between. But anyway, she is great, well done her, truly amazing.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
Stimulation perhaps. Everyone can take from it what they will. What I took from it was that when things seem too big and scary here, it isn't really that significant, and I should calm down (depends on the gravity of the situation of course, but most of the time it's easy to overreact).

And then when things seem so brilliant here, I should make the most of the situation, and experience the biological phenomenon that is my consciousness with as much self awareness as I can. It's a helpful thing to remember when you are maki decisions too, because it helps to put your goals in perspective. What's the most important thing to me? Because my experience of this tiny moment of life is the most important thing to me, and I should try to make it the best it can be. Don't confuse that with selfishness because important things to me include being as big a positive effect on the world as I can.

I don't know. No need to be humiliated, because we are an incredible, special phenomenon just as all conscious and sentient life is. Small things can be important too.

Also, it's entertaining. And I was in awe, I think it's pretty cool how ridiculously big the universe and other stuff in it is.

Make of it what you feel like making of it, and it doesn't matter what that is.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
RYV VYHXLCWEMIH  I think it's true that a lie/deception/exaggeration that taps into strong feelings people have can very often be more politically effective than the truth.

The ability nowadays to have any untruths spreading with such speed and with the echo chamber (of showing you things you like, no fact checking involved like editors of newspapers might do) is something worrying, no matter where you lie on a political issue. Now more than ever, two contradictory facts can be espoused by two sides and believed fanatically by some supporters, and one must be wrong, and yet the echo chamber and the truth that an interesting lie often will work better than a less interesting truth is having its effects.

I agree that postmodern is the wrong label, and that the article could be better, but I think there needs to be some analysis about how easily mass numbers of people can be convinced that scientists are wrong about climate change/GMOs, or economics experts are wrong etc. and greater awareness of the problem.

comment.comment:
Sort of get why you say that, (and don't take this too seriously) but: "To what extent do you think the stagnation of innovation in pizza restaurants reflects an example of the complacency class you've described?"

It's not a completely fair analogy, but the point I'm making is that people like what pizza is right now, seem to be using it a lot, and probably would be a bit annoyed if the place they have gone for pizza for the last 5-6 years was to change the base of their pizza from wheat flour to rice flour, or the tomato sauce to red pepper sauce etc.

If they want to bring out another product, or if another restaurant offers other food, then that's fine, but there is no need for a pizza place to make sushi or noodles.

I'm not sure it's something to be concerned about. There are plenty of alternative social media sites which do all sorts of quirky things (see naan breads/focaccia) but they just aren't as good as pizza. Which is why neither pizza nor Facebook is trying to become like focaccia or Pinterest.

Do you think there is any truth to that? Or do you think that innovation should always proceed regardless of whether it actually makes things better. Or perhaps you think that things should always improve and that there is never any excuse for not doing so (see pizza).

Just a few thoughts :)

comment.comment:
With no agency, there is no free will as most people see it. No agency means that the sense of self on which we blame most of our successes and failures is in fact not in our control at the level of physics, and as such credit for "success" or "failure" however humans may define them must go to our genetics, environment, and the Heisenberg (to put it simply, to the atoms and forces that make us up), rather than being in some way our own. (This is my current position on the situation)

On a societal level, we perhaps need to continue with our custom of blaming people for actions and rewarding them for their failures. These incentives are likely required for progress (if we think progress is a good in itself!). I think people may not like to think they have a lack of agency (people always create narratives explaining why they do what they do).

comment.comment:
NUWBULS OLXYLH firstly, please tag me, because it doesn't come up on my notifications otherwise.

The meme is saying that many religious people turn to their religions out of a poor understanding of science and reason. The fact that there exist people who seem to have a good grasp of science and reason who are also religious is irrelevant to the meme.

The suspension of belief is an incredibly powerful thing. It isn't surprising that somebody could engage in "doublethink" (to steal from George Orwell) to hold two contradictory beliefs at the same time because both are too strongly ingrained in their psyche to ignore.

My worldview is categorically NOT based on the assertion or authority of these "new atheist 'scientists'" you seem so skeptical of. In fact it's based on a lot of thought and sound reasoning. The fact that people like Bertrand Russell, Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens, and couuuuntless other incredibly respected figures (who I would say hold a lot of authority) agree with me is not fundamental to my belief.

Religious institutions have always been against science, because their power is based in "knowing" something that the people they preach to don't. Science attacks the God of the gaps, reducing their significance (as is happening).

There are statistics which show that educational attainment correlates with likelihood of being a non-believer. There will always be anomalies.

Now if you'd like, we can discuss the logic and evidence behind our beliefs rather than just appealing to random figures of authority and anecdotal evidence. Let me know if you're keen.

comment.comment: A genius won't stand out in a society where there are many of them spread across many fields. The increased complexity of life and the division of labour means that the geniuses aren't working on such broad paradigm-shifting ideas such as calculus and relativity, but instead very specific and complex problems in some fields, and this means they will never get the same recognition as those lucky few (with the education and freedom to pursue their genius) who built the earlier foundations. Ramanujan could just as easily have never been unearthed, or others like him. Nowadays he would become a financial analyst or work in some high level software development, and we wouldn't know his name. Alex K. Chen

comment.comment:
I mean it's not the most impressive article I've ever read.

I think it perhaps discounts the fact that if there are many more "geniuses", then it would funnily enough seem like there are less because they wouldn't be considered geniuses anymore. I would suggest that we have more people on a par with the geniuses of old than ever before, but just that it isn't something that makes people realllly stand out as it did in the past. 

With the division of labour, our geniuses affect their own field greatly, but because their own field has advanced to such a point that it is complex enough to fill most of one genius' time, we no longer have the philosopher-mathematicians, or the inventors who spread their time across disciplines, because more progress comes from them all specialising into different things and pushing the boundaries as far as they can in a smaller field.

That means you don't get the household names, because they are instead involved with how to solve the battery problem, or studying quantum physics or the origin of life or higher level mathematics, or writing philosophy etc.

There is far more competition to be a genius now than ever before, whether it is a creative one or an analytical one. Very few can stand out from the rest, and so this glut of geniuses has the appearance of a famine.

comment.comment:
Now that would be true if firms didn't base themselves in the UK based on its access to the single market, and it would be true if our massive success in financial markets wasn't in a large part based on the fact that we have access to the free movement of capital across Europe (making here a great place to do all of your Europe investing from). And then also we would be exacerbating our people shortages in the care sector and hospital sector, and perhaps the education sector as well, where we just seem unable to get enough people qualified for the job (arguably that could be blamed on a lack of domestic investment in education, but if we don't do that then we need to take people from other countries). It isn't just about trade.

We have come to rely heavily on foreign investment across a lot of sectors. Because of this, we need to continue making ourselves attractive to these investors, or you are likely to have the situation where Frankfurt and Paris try to tempt away our financial services, and then all of the countries in Europe would be trying to incentivise the exporting firms in the UK to move to them. It isn't just about trade.

Also there are very real spiral effects in economies (see Venezuela and Argentina for some admittedly over exaggerated examples), and so a short term shock and depression disincentivises investment, means lower tax revenues, therefore less government spending etc etc etc.

Now I am not seer gazing into a crystal ball, but there are a lot of things that would have to work out pretty perfectly if we left. Pitfalls everywhere, and certainly a less attractive country to invest into. 

Also most of the leaving decisions we make when rehashing our laws over the two year grace period would not be made in parliament because there isn't time for that many votes. Unelected officials would be making sweeping decisions on vast areas of laws (which I know is a fetish of yours) ;)

On the topic of unelected officials, the commission is made up of one person from each member state, selected by the current elected leader of that country (Cameron appointed ours), and they have a duty to support and provide the views and opinions of their party/that head of state. So yes they aren't elected, but they are part of the democratic process, and their presence their is based on democracy. Just so you know what leave means when they say "unelected Eurocrats are running everything" when really it's the council of country leaders that decides on the direction of the EU.

Anyway, look forward to hearing your economic analysis of the issues I have raised.

comment.comment:
I could give just as many examples of times when change was a bad idea as I could for when change is a good idea. Change worked then because to change was better than not to change. It wouldn't work now because to change is worse than not to change.

If Europe becomes a genuine drag, we can leave. As it stands, leaving won't get us sovereignty back (sovereignty and fully accountable government is now impossible in the global economy, as outside economic forces have irresistible effects often - see us housing market leading to one of the worst global recessions in history), and leaving also won't get us control over immigration, unless we lose our only access to a free market of any sort.

Scaremongering would be scaring people based on unfounded claims, or scaring them more than the risks merit. Prudent advice for the future instead warns people of the serious risks, that could cause fairly wide spread harm to our interconnected economy. We all do worse when it shrinks, and as far as I can tell, a lot of companies are worried about our access to the single market going (which includes free movement of good, labour and capital..)
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment:
The euro was a terrible idea. We all know that. But we were also in the EU in those years. It was in fact entering the Euro that was the Unknown there, and we rightly avoided it.

This is not about fear. But where it is possible to make judgements about how the future might pan out (prediction is too strong perhaps), and it seems clear that one way holds more risk and less reward than the other, it is not "fearful" to choose what seems like the best option.

To become a nation state of Europe would be a terrible idea, but that doesn't mean that to be part of the EU (commonly agreeing rules that allow us to trade and interact with eachother) is a bad idea. Not adopting the Euro was a good idea (and was by far the preferred choice of industry and most politicians, like most good ideas usually are), and adopting it would have been terrible, but that doesn't mean leaving Europe has the same characteristics.

comment.comment: GUG PULLYNN  Onto the EU. Okay so we have established that the commission is by elected, but it is however partly democratic (the people who fill it are chosen as a indirect of our general elections, much like cabinet ministers). BOTH the European Parliament AND the commission have to agree about legislation. They both effectively have Vetoes (don't know if I have spelt that right). I think it massively reduces whatever this loosely defined (debatably existent) "democratic deficit" that you talk about. If deciding on everything that affects our countries fortunes is what you believe we should have, know that it is impossible in an economy that is interdependent with others. Regardless if we are in or out or shake it all about, our government will never be fully accountable to us because of Global Market Forces. These GMFs are determined by the governments of all countries worldwide. And their trade deals. And the multi national corporations that decide to invest or not to invest in a country, and the movement of wealth and investment decisions etc etc etc. Our being in the EU gives us more control over Global Market Forces, and thus the impact our government has on it should form a part of its accountability to the populace. We don't dictate the world economy, and we should accept that we don't dictate trading laws. They are reached by consensus. And if you want a lot of countries to agree, you need to get them all in a room regularly where they can talk about what they want and vote on it. So that they all get a say.

comment.comment: è´¾æå¥  The men who set up these institutions did not do so because of religion. They were religious, but as you said, correlation does not imply causation. The Arabic numerals are no more a product of Islam than the English language (or the World Wide Web or indeed any discovery) is the product of Protestantism. Religion did keep order, as a method of population control, where the all powerful and all seeing Deity of whatever sort would punish you for your crimes (an ever present secret police force). Many Greek philosophers didn't believe in their Gods, and their religion rarely if ever had an affect on their thirst for learning and ingenuity. Same for the Romans, Egyptians etc. They had religions, and scientific progress. But correlation does not imply causation. It is human curiosity that we can point to in each case, amplified by free time not having to feed clothe and house oneself, which drives science and progress.

comment.comment:
It's hard for us to think that it isn't about immigration when by and large, the issue that seems to come up the most when reading/watching out campaigners happens to be the movement of people. The number of times I've heard "strain on our services" is unbelievable. Not all are xenophobic or racist, most that I know aren't. An uncontrolled policy on immigration is by and large what we need to support our ageing population that will need a higher and higher net outflow of money from the government pot, which with our current working population (extrapolated into the future assuming less immigration) would really hurt our fiscal health as a country.

I admit the faults of the EU freely. But it is worth noting, none of them are as bad as Remain makes out. The EU commission is made up of unelected officials, yes. But these officials are chosen by the governments of their respective countries (who are elected). They are there to put forward the agenda of their political party, and may as well be our Prime minister as far as any of us are concerned.

Not entirely sure what you mean about EU trade deals, and yes the EU isn't healthy at the moment, but it is recovering. It's rampant neoliberalism that's to blame for that (and all of the crises).

We don't have to pay an extra 2 billion, and France and Germany aren't getting massive reductions. We pay a reasonable amount given the size of our economy and the benefits we receive.

My understanding of fishing law isn't up there. Seems U lurk that we have to give people fish though. Not sure.

Jobs will be lost. In ten or twenty years we'll have major shortages of doctors, teachers, carers and manual labourers. Our budget will be harder to balance than ever without plenty of working age people working hard and contributing tax. I'm proud to be British, and I'm proud to share those values with anyone who cares to come and respect them and live by them.

I'm not going to tell anyone how to vote, because it's an intensely complicated and difficult decision, but personally, I see a better future for us and the world inside the EU.

No but my point was that we don't "need" to do that in the absolute sense. If we want to live sustainably then we need to do it, or if we want to respect animals and safeguard the world for future generations then we need to do it, but there is no absolute need, the need is predicated on stuff that we want to do. And if we manage to reverse global warming and live sustainably, and safeguard our planet, then we aren't a virus that needs to be eradicated, instead what we are right now is a destructive species that is learning and slowly prioritising sustainability more. We don't need to be eradicated.

To clarify, I know we are very destructive and we NEED to become more sustainable as a species, but we don't NEED to be eradicated.

comment.comment: Gerry you didn't get the point of what I was saying because you don't understand how determinism works. The brain is subject to the same cause and effect rules as the rest of the universe, and it is the system we use to make our decision. Different systems (the brains of different people) will make different choices in situations, based on how that system is constructed. It is constructed by both past experiences and genetic code, and nothing else. So it becomes not about excuses for actions, but understanding what makes people do those things, and understanding that a starving man will steal and if your family was tortured you will kill in vengeance. There are reasons people do what they do, and suffering breeds more suffering in human nature, so my point it not to excuse the crimes, but to say that torture is not an appropriate response.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comment.comment: Find out about determinism and consider how people make decisions. Their crimes happen because of how their past experiences have shaped them - for example an abused child might be more likely to commit crimes later, and those raised in care have a far greater propensity to end up in prison. A choice isn't always as simple as it seems, try a bit of empathy.

comment.comment: If through our raising of them, we can enhance their lives through giving them food and protecting them from hunters, is it not better for us to do this than to leave them to struggle in the wild? More animals have better lives today than if we were to stop using their produce. We can definitely try to stop bad practices where the animals suffer, but I don't believe that animals constantly hiding from predators and desperately scavenging for food to stay alive would be better off. Freedom is an abstract concept, as is meaning. Freedom is not always beneficial (people commit crimes and then we lock them up). Cannon fodder is where people die for no reason, the animals (like plants) are being raised for the sole purpose of feeding people. If you think that we cannot know anything about another being's experience because we aren't able to feel how they feel, then don't eat plants or insects either, and who knows if freedom might mean something to energy.

comment.comment:
The animals are not being used as slaves. The key issue is the capability of abstract thought, or sentience. Without it, life has little meaning (I wouldn't see the point in being alive if I were lobotomised and lost my sense of self).

Suffering. The key word. Slaves suffer, so it is unacceptable. Battery hens suffer - unacceptable. Free range chickens and cows and pigs etc, don't suffer in life, and indeed have better lives than they could possibly expect in the wild (starving/hunted). Our ability to have abstract thought, contemplate purpose, and enjoy higher pleasures than just the physical are what differentiates us from animals. It is not superiority in terms of deserving to dominate, but instead it means that we can suffer in an abstract way as well, and so to avoid that we cannot be raised as animals can be. An animal has never asked "what am I doing with my louder" or contemplated the higher ideals of freedom. Freedom is meaningless to them because of this, and it is only their physical and social circumstance that matters.

comment.comment: Even then, Google is likely to link to a more popular link, and the links which are most widely read and back linked to are likely to be those that the majority of the voters support. (The AI wants to give you the link that is most relevant, and one of the metrics is how much activity there is about it). But the impression I got was that they were suggesting that the search engines were putting the politicians higher up and that that was causing more people to vote for them.
comment.author: ACWBUYF.XYFFS

comments.title: ACWBUYF.XYFFS replied to his own comment.

comment.comment: Hey stop conflating correlation with cause. Ugh, come on.

comment.comment: I'm against cruelty in all its forms, but animals and humans don't have the same experiences. If you are going to personify animals, then ask: what is the meaning of life? Why are they here? What are their long term goals? I don't believe that most animals have goals past wishing to stay alive (which has been evolutionarily programmed into all things), and I don't know if any of us, let alone animals, have a "meaning of life". How should a pig be living it's life? If it isn't very different to having all its food brought to it and having endless leisure time, then isn't the eating of their meat a good thing for the species, as more total pig hours are lived because of it? Unhappy animals is wrong, but I don't think that the consumption of animal products is. Animals don't have the capacity for abstract thought and existential problems with why they exist, so if their existence itself is a positive experience that they wouldn't want to give up, should we not maximise the number of positive experiences we can create (and consider the sale of meat and animal products the means of funding said endeavour)?

comment.comment: QUNBYLCHY JCWEYLS  fair enough, although I would suggest that you consider that we will have no free trade deals when we leave and so everything will become more expensive, and legislative expenses will also be huge. It will take 5 years just to sort out how we will relate to the EU and a lot of people will lose their jobs. The hospitality sector (amongst others) will have a huge employment shortage, and your household bills will go up due to import tariffs that the EU will definitely impose. We will have to renegotiate our ties with NATO and indeed all military, medical, and scientific links with Europe, as well as it limiting our movement to going over there. We will no longer share intelligence as closely, and above all, we just don't know how anything is going to improve. There hasn't been a single politician who has come up with a reasonable suggestion as to how things will change positively when we leave.

comment.comment: Methodology matters when making key decisions. The Patriot act may have been a very dangerous piece of legislation, however much like with extremist views, dangerous pieces of legislation need to be debated. The House of Representatives had just voted for the USA Freedom Act which was effectively the opposite. I don't know enough about that situation to comment more. I agree there isn't a simple line that can be drawn, but much like value judgements we make in other walks of life (see reasonable doubt), judgements should still be made. Just because important discussions take place in secrecy, that doesn't mean that it's ok for the publicly available debates to become useless whenever someone decides filibustering is appropriate. It is aiming to make debates Int debates, to allow both sides to put their views forwards on important issues and ensure those issues get discussed. That's what it is aiming to achieve.

comment.comment: The maths this "Doctor" does is a pile of shit. there is a 3 out of 10 chance that somebody would get three of those correct, not 1 in 729 (see maths at bottom). Also if the boy was telepathic he would have gotten all 5 right. Telepathy is not being particularly good at guessing, it is being able to genuinely read someone's mind. Also the languages (at least the ones demonstrated) look like the absolute basics, and the mother could have taught him those without him having superpowers. There is a reason why that "Doctor" no longer works at Harvard, it's because she seems to be stupid and gullible. If you aren't convinced look up some of her other work. It isn't 1/9 * 3, it is 1 - (8/9 * 3) = 0.297668
